title: London Tube Analysis
text:
This was for the Urban Simulation module assignment for the Urban Spatial Science Msc at the Bartlett’s Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis, University College London.
The aim of this project was to critically assess the resilience of London’s Underground network taking into consideration the infrastructural network and then commuter flows.

title: London Tube Analysis
text:
This was for the Urban Simulation module assignment for the Urban Spatial Science Msc at the Bartlett’s Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis, University College London.
The aim of this project was to critically assess the resilience of London’s Underground network taking into consideration the infrastructural network and then commuter flows.

title: London Tube Analysis
text:
Objectives
This project was done using Python programming.

Rank important stations by centrality measures.
Investigate the impacts of station closures or disruptions through node removal.
Create a weighted network by including commuter flows.
Explore hypothetical scenarios, including a decrease in jobs in Canary Wharf and their impacts on commuter flows.

title: Predicting Carbon Emissions from London’s Residential Sector
text:
This project was for my Data Science for Spatial Systems module as part of my Urban Spatial Science course at CASA, UCL.
The aim of this project was to use machine learning to assess the effectiveness of physical housing factors and demographic factors in predicting carbon emissions from London’s residential sector.

title: Predicting Carbon Emissions from London’s Residential Sector
text:
This project was for my Data Science for Spatial Systems module as part of my Urban Spatial Science course at CASA, UCL.
The aim of this project was to use machine learning to assess the effectiveness of physical housing factors and demographic factors in predicting carbon emissions from London’s residential sector.

title: Predicting Carbon Emissions from London’s Residential Sector
text:
Objectives
This project was completed using Python programming.

Clean and manipulate data.
Assess for spatial autocorrelation.
Include spatial lag to the data for the machine learning models.
Create optimal XGBoost and Random Forest models and use.
Conduct a permutation features importance to determine which factors had the most predictive power over each machine learning model.
Assess the performance on the models using R Squared and root-mean-squared-error values.

title: Predicting Carbon Emissions from London’s Residential Sector
text:
Outputs
The full project can be found on this Github page.

title: Spatial Analysis of London’s Residential Carbon Emissions
text:
This was my undergraduate dissertation project for the Geography with Spatial Data Science course at King’s College London.
The aim of this project was to investigate the geographies and causes of carbon emissions from household electricity and gas consumption in London. Then using the findings, assess the implications on the city’s Retrofit London Housing Action Plan.

title: Spatial Analysis of London’s Residential Carbon Emissions
text:
This was my undergraduate dissertation project for the Geography with Spatial Data Science course at King’s College London.
The aim of this project was to investigate the geographies and causes of carbon emissions from household electricity and gas consumption in London. Then using the findings, assess the implications on the city’s Retrofit London Housing Action Plan.

title: Spatial Analysis of London’s Residential Carbon Emissions
text:
Objectives

Clean and manipulate data using Python programming.
Visualise the spatial distribution of carbon emission changes in London.
Determine if spatial autocorrelation is present using Moran’s I.
Visualise hot and cold spots for carbon emissions through a local indicator of spatial association analysis.
Conduct spatial regression analysis to understand causes of residential emissions from energy consumption.

title: Spatial Analysis of London’s Residential Carbon Emissions
London Tube Analysis
text:
This was for the Urban Simulation module assignment for the Urban Spatial Science Msc at the Bartlett’s Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis, University College London.
The aim of this project was to critically assess the resilience of London’s Underground network taking into consideration the infrastructural network and then commuter flows.

title: Walkability Analysis
text:
The aim of this project was to assess how walkability to varying modes of public transport differ in two cities in the UK, Portsmouth and Southampton.
To assess this, a walkability index was produced for points of interest (POIs) that relate to public transport in each city. A routing analysis was performed using Pandana to calculate walking times from every node in the network to the nearest 10 POIs, with the limit of only calculating travel times that are within a 20 minute walk.
The betweenness centrality was also used as a proxy for predicted traffic flow to determine areas which may be experiencing high traffic. This was then used in conjunction with the walkability index to assess areas which may be experiencing high traffic but lack easily accessible public transport stops or stations.
This was done using Pandana and OSMnx on Python.

title: Walkability Analysis
text:

The betweenness centrality was also used as a proxy for predicted traffic flow to determine areas which may be experiencing high traffic. This was then used in conjunction with the walkability index to assess areas which may be experiencing high traffic but lack easily accessible public transport stops or stations.
This was done using Pandana and OSMnx on Python.
